bibl.title: Letter fragment from Thomas C. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, [May 26, 1908]

div1.p: Thomas Lazear writes that Representative Dalzell guided the pension bill through the House.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Thomas C. Lazear to Mabel H. Lazear, [May 26, 1908]
div1.opener:
2
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
480 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
div1.p:
Any kind or by petition of reward, and I assure you that
you and Mrs Carroll would never have succeeded
if he had not taken the matter in hand as he did
at the onset and persevered in its accomplishment
to the last- While you should be grateful to members of
Congress who promised to vote for the measure, the persons
to whom you are most indebted are Mr Morse, Hon John
Dalzell and Dr. Mansfelde- Without the cooperation
of those three gentlemen, the bill would never have
come to a vote in the House of Representatives where
the fight was carried on, for you know that no opposition
was encountered in the Senate- The trouble in the House
was all due to the Stubborn refusual of the Pension Committee
to report the bill to that body for action- The chairman
of that Committee, Mr Loudenslager was inexorable
and without his consent the speaker of the House Mr Cannon-
would never have allowed the bill to be called upon-
Mr Dalzell was throughly convinced of this and watched
his opportunity to introduce the new bill when Mr Loudenslager
and Mr Cannon should be absent from Washington- But
opportunity came and the new bill was then presented
by Mr Dalzell and was passed unanimously- Mr D. had
already interviewed the members and secured this promise
to vote for the bill- If one member had voted
against it, it would have been postponed indefinitely.
3
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
480 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
One did say to Mr D. that he would oppose it but
when Mr D. replied it would break his heart if he
did so, that person after a few moments consideration
approached Mr D and said he would vote with
the others and he did so- All was accomplised
in a short time and the same forenoon Mr D wired
me the result and I immediately sent a telegram
to you which you seem to have received about two hours
before I sent it, such is the difference between Eastern
and Pacific time.-

The credit of changing the bill so as to
provide for an “annuity” instead of a “pension” should
be accorded to Mr Dalzell- It is true, however, that
a few days before the new bill was introduced I
wrote to Dr Mansfelde expressing the wish that
such a change should be made and suggested
that the relief we asked for might be called
an “annuity”, So as to take the whole matter
out of the hands of the Pension Committee-
I had no idea that the same thought
would occur to others - But it did occur
to Mr Dalzell though I was not aware of
this until I saw a copy of the new bill
after it had been passed- This was merely
4
LAZEAR AND ORR
ATTORNEYS AT LAW
480 FOURTH AVENUE
PITTSBURGH, PA.
THOS C. LAZEAR CHAS P. ORR
JESSE T. LAZEAR
a coincidence easily explained by the fact that Mr Dalzell
and I are both lawyers and knew the legal meaning
of the magic word “annuity”- I never suggested the
change to Mr Dalzell and I am confident that
he naturally fell into the same idea as I did
without suggestions from any person- It was
all original with him and he is entitled
exclusively to the credit-

Next week I expect to visit Windsor
and to remain there three or four weeks- I want
to have the pleasure of the society of Kates family
and Sister Charlie, as I call Mrs Sweitzer, and to
do all I can for the comfort of that family- The
sudden death of Thomas Seth has been very distressing
to them all- After that visit I may take
a trip to Canada with my son Jesse and grandson
John Lazear-

I suppose you have received your first
payment from Washington on account of your
annuity- It was due on the 23rd of June.
With much love to you all
div1.closer:
Yours Affectionately Thos C. Lazear Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear
Santa Barbara Cal
